_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

Where the deceased individuals have been: The monk Sāḷha - realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life
The nun Nandā - been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world
The layman Sudatta - a once-returner; he will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering
The laywoman Sujātā - a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening
The explanation of the Dhamma called ‘th: A noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha
A noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching
A noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Saṅgha
A noble disciple has the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones
A noble disciple has the ethical conduct leading to immersion
The declaration of a noble disciple who: "I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm."
"I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld."
"I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am bound for awakening."
